instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
The 4 cd3215coo are heating up, I replaced all of them. Still 5v
voltage readings
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_ISOL</SIGNAL>-3.391v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>-3.354v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>-1.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
I can't find  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_ISOL</SIGNAL> in schematic.

If all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages present, try DFU mode.
Machine tries to start with known good battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
The macbook is working perfectly well with battery just that it’s not charging.
after changing the 4cd3215c00 all the ports are drawing 5v but one out of the 4ports is not drawing current.
The topic should be not charging. Sorry for the mistake.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
Battery will not charge, until get 20V on USB-C ports.
Compare diode mode readings around all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
Be sure to check all points in the same way (red probe at ground).

"one out of the 4ports is not drawing current"
Which port is that one (reffered to schematic)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
J3300 red probe on ground. 
No resistance on 
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_USB_TOP_N</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_USB_BOT_N</SIGNAL> 
And the port without current is from this connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
Mentioned lines correspond to JB500!

Remove USB-C connector from shell and check its pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
Sorry my bad. It’s JB500 ports are drawing 5v with current. 
but on j3300 both ports are drawing 5v but one of them is not drawing current.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not drawing 20v
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings between the lines of USB ports.
Remove the connectors from the shell and inspect the terminals.
